Header: Indian state battles ‘rat fever’ outbreak after worst floods in a century
Content: The southern Indian state of Kerala is battling an outbreak of a bacterial disease that authorities suspect has killed dozens of people since mid-August following the worst flooding in a century. Additional Director of Health said there had been roughly 300 suspected cases since of what is locally called the rat fever the waterborne disease leptospirosis transmitted via the urine of infected animals, with symptoms including muscle pain and fever. There had been nearly 200 confirmed cases. The surge in the disease comes after torrential rain beginning on August 8th flooded almost the entire state, killing hundreds of people, destroying thousands of homes and causing at least $2.81 billion worth of damage.
